journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: An optimal traction, braking, and steering coordination strategy for stability and manoeuvrability of a six-wheel drive and six-wheel steer vehicle

article-meta.aff: 1Program in Automotive Engineering, Seoul National University, Seoul, Republic of Korea
2School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Seoul National University, Seoul, Republic of Korea
3Samsung Techwin, Changwon, Kyungnam-do, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: *School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Seoul National University, San 56-1 Shinlim-dong, Seoul, Republic of Korea. email: kyi@snu.ac.kr

abstract.p: This paper describes an optimal traction, braking and steering coordination to improve vehicle lateral stability and manoeuvrability of a six-wheel driving/six-wheel steering (6WD/6WS) vehicle. The optimal coordination controller consists of an upper and lower level controller. The upper level controller determines front, middle steering angle, desired net yaw moment, and longitudinal net force according to the reference velocity and steering angle corresponding to a manual driver. The desired yaw moment is calculated by sliding-mode control theory. Based on the desired longitudinal net force, yaw moment, and tyre force information as inputs from the upper level controller, the lower level controller determines distributed lateral tyre forces and longitudinal tyre force on each wheel in proportion to the size of the friction circle of each wheel. The size of a friction circle is estimated using longitudinal/lateral velocity, yaw rate, wheel torque, and wheel angular velocity. Vehicle–driver–controller closed-loop simulations have been conducted to investigate the improved performance of the proposed optimal coordination controller over a conventional direct yaw moment controller (DYC) of the vehicle equipped with a mechanical drive system.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: An independent six-wheel drive/six-wheel steering vehicle (6WD/6WS) mechanism is adopted for use in a special-purpose, military armoured vehicle to enhance its steering performance and drive capability on both off-road and on-road conditions. Figure 1 shows the several types of tracked, four-wheel, and six-wheel vehicles.

caption.p: Tracked, four-wheel, and six-wheel combat vehicles [1]

sec.p: The six-wheeled vehicle is expected to have a better performance than a tracked vehicle and a four-wheeled vehicle in terms of its capability of obstacle navigation and off-road and on-road high-speed manoeuvring. A six-wheeled vehicle has advantages over a tracked and four-wheeled vehicle for capacity of manoeuvre and drive. From the point of view of drive performance, a tracked vehicle is suitable for off-road driving conditions, since longitudinal tyre friction forces can be guaranteed because of the armoured track. However, a tracked vehicle cannot drive in high-speed and on-road conditions. A four-wheeled or six-wheeled vehicle is suitable for on-road driving conditions. A wheel can rotate faster and more silently than a track of the vehicle. A wheel has limitations of vertical tyre force in order to endure gravity of the vehicle according to tyre characteristics. In the heavy vehicle case, the vertical tyre force of a 4WD vehicle is much greater than that of a 6WD vehicle. In order to support significant vertical tyre force, the size of the wheel and tyre has to increase. The suspension capacity also has to be larger than that of a 6WD vehicle, because the vertical tyre force changes drastically. The size and a capacity are limited to satisfy specifications according to the manufacture and system design. Therefore, a type of six-wheeled vehicle is applied to design combat vehicles for on-road and off-road combat operations. From the point of view of fail-safe, the six-wheeled vehicle is useful for several fault situations. If a flat tyre occurred while driving, a four-wheeled vehicle could not drive. However, the six-wheeled vehicle can conduct military operations continuously. Therefore, the six-wheeled vehicle is robust against the failure of actuator systems.

Combat vehicles need to be equipped with a lateral stability control system, because most driving conditions are at high speed, drastically turning manoeuvres, and on slippery roads. Various methods have been studied and actively developed to improve lateral stability of a four-wheeled vehicle [2–7]. Recently, researches of six-wheeled vehicle stability control have been conducted. Huh and colleagues have set the middle wheel steering angle to half of the front wheel steering angle and controlled the rear wheel steering to minimize the side slip angle of a six-wheeled vehicle [8]. Jackson and Crolla have adopted the yaw rate control method using the direct yaw moment control (DYC) to improve the stability of their six-wheeled vehicle during cornering [9]. Chen and colleagues have controlled the middle and rear wheel steering angle using the linear quadratic regulator (LQR) technique with integral control [10], while An and colleagues have controlled the front, middle, and rear wheel steering angles and velocity [11, 12]. Vehicles used in previous research were equipped with engine, transmission, and differential gears. In these vehicles, only brake torque is used to generate the desired yaw moment and output drive torques on each wheel, which cannot be determined independently. Previously, a stability controller has been designed without consideration of changes in each wheel load condition. Performance of the stability controller is limited by low friction or severe manoeuvring driving conditions.

By virtue of the recent development of hybrid systems and in-wheel motors, drive and brake torque can be independently determined. Recently in the defence industry, electric and hybrid systems have been developed to improve driving performance and energy efficiency. These systems require a control system that can connect a driver to drive, brake, and steer-by-wire systems. In this paper, to enhance the stability and manoeuvrability, an optimal coordination controller is proposed for a 6WD/6WS vehicle, as shown in Fig. 2. Compared to a six-wheeled vehicle equipped with a mechanical and DYC system, the proposed 6WD/6WS vehicle is an x-by-wire system that is able to control driving, braking torque, and steering wheel angle independently. With these functions, the proposed vehicle with the optimal coordination controller is superior to those of a mechanical drive system equipped with the DYC control system.

caption.p: Configuration of a mechanical driver system and an electric hybrid driver system

sec.p: The optimal coordination controller needs to take into account the force acting on the road and tyre. The proposed optimal coordination controller consists of an upper and lower level controller. Inputs of the upper level controller are the steering wheel angle and the reference velocity. The steering angle is determined through a manual driver. The reference velocity is calculated to meet the required acceleration and deceleration. Outputs of the upper level controller are the desired longitudinal tyre net force and yaw moment, which are necessary for driving and steering motion. Taking the desired longitudinal tyre net force, yaw moment, and tyre force information as inputs, the lower level controller determines the additional front steering angle and distributed longitudinal tyre force on each wheel. The size of a friction circle is estimated using vehicle states, which can be measured by sensors. The friction circle information is used to coordinate additional optimal tyre forces for the lower level controller. Vehicle–driver–controller closed-loop simulations have been conducted to investigate the improved performance of the proposed optimal coordination controller over a conventional DYC of the vehicle equipped with a mechanical drive system.

sec.title: 2 Vehicle Dynamic Model of a 6WD/6WS Vehicle
2.1 Body dynamics
sec.p: In this paper, a six-wheeled vehicle is modelled as an object with 24 degrees-of-freedom (DOF). The full vehicle model consists of six DOF translational and rotational dynamic models of the sprung mass, six suspension models, six wheel dynamic models and six steering dynamic models, as shown in Fig. 3. Wheel dynamics contains an in-wheel motor, brake system and tyre models.

caption.p: Three-dimensional dynamic model for a 6WD/6WS vehicle

sec.p: A sprung mass dynamic equation consists of a translational (Newtonian) dynamic equation and a rotational (Euler) dynamic equation as follows
Unsprung mass dynamics includes suspension and wheel dynamics. The state equation for suspension dynamics is given as
The state equation for wheel dynamics contains moment of inertia, wheel angular acceleration, drive torque, and longitudinal tyre force as follows
The steering wheel angle is determined by a steering angle command. The steering dynamics is given as
Longitudinal and lateral tyre forces are calculated by slip ratio and slip angle, using the Pacejka tyre model [13] as shown in Fig. 4.

caption.p: Longitudinal and lateral tyre models

sec.p: The full vehicle dynamic model makes it possible to analyse a 6WD/6WS vehicle’s manoeuvrability and to design the driving controller. Table 1 shows the specifications of a 6WD/6WS vehicle.

caption.p: Specifications for the 6WD/6WS vehicle

sec.title: 2.2 Motor dynamics
sec.p: A 6WD/6WS vehicle equipped with six in-wheel motors is able to provide differential tracking and braking drive modes, because motors can be controlled independently. In order to satisfy the required performance of the vehicle, a motor capacity of 15 kW was selected. Its total motor capacity is 90 kW. Figure 5 represents the structure of in-wheel motors and a torque–angular velocity diagram. The maximum torque depends on the capacity of the in-wheel motor and is determined according to wheel angular velocity.

caption.p: Motor specification curve and an in-wheel motor

sec.p: The in-wheel motor is modelled as a first-order system, where the time constant (τmotor) of the motor dynamics is 0.05 s, and Tin is the torque command and Tout is the output torque

sec.title: 3 Optimal Coordination Controller Development
sec.p: The proposed x-by-wire system for a 6WD/6WS vehicle is able to control the traction and handling independently. Therefore, in order to design a controller for manoeuvrability and stability of the 6WD/6WS vehicle, an optimal coordination algorithm needs to be developed. The optimal coordination algorithm determines the steering wheel angle, drive torques, and brake torques on six wheels, respectively. These are given from the driver’s intended steering wheel angle and the desired vehicle velocity. In this paper, a mechanical system equipped with a DYC has been developed to compare the proposed optimal coordination controller with respect to performance of manoeuvrability and stability. The mechanical system consists of mechanical steering, braking, drive, and differential gear. For more performance improvement, the mechanical system needs to include the DYC system. Figure 6 shows a block diagram of these vehicle systems.

caption.p: Mechanical drive, DYC, and optimal coordination control of a 6WD/6WS vehicle

sec.title: 3.1 Optimal coordination controller design
sec.p: A 6WD/6WS vehicle equipped with six in-wheel motors is able to operate differential tractive and braking torques. An optimal coordination controller includes a lateral stability controller and a longitudinal velocity controller. The optimal coordination controller consists of upper and lower level controllers. An optimal distribution method is used to design a controller. Inputs of the upper level controller are steering angle and reference velocity. Steering angles are determined through a manual driver. The reference velocity is calculated to meet the required acceleration and deceleration. Outputs of the upper level controller are desired longitudinal tyre net force and yaw moment, which are necessary for driving and steering motion. Taking the desired longitudinal tyre net force, yaw moment, and tyre force information as inputs, the lower level controller determines the additional front steering angle and longitudinal tyre force on each wheel. Figure 7 shows a block diagram of the optimal coordination controller.

caption.p: Optimal coordination controller block diagram

sec.title: 3.2 Upper level controller design
sec.p: By taking the steering angle determined through the manual driver and the reference velocity as inputs, the upper level controller determines the desired longitudinal tyre net force and yaw moment. Figure 8 shows a block diagram of the upper level controller.

caption.p: Upper level controller

sec.p: In the upper level controller, the desired yaw rate is expressed as the proportional gain k and first-order transfer function. The desired yaw moment is calculated to force the vehicle to follow the desired yaw rate using sliding-mode control theory [14]. Moreover, velocity error is calculated and fed to the proportional, integral, and dervative (PID) controller to generate the desired longitudinal tyre net force. The steering angle is determined for middle wheels according to the Ackerman steering geometric features of a 6WD/6WS vehicle.

sec.title: 3.2.1 Steering angle determination for a steer-by-wire system
sec.p: The front steering wheel angle generates the lateral motion of a 4WD vehicle. Therefore, the turning manoeuvre of the vehicle can be determined by Ackerman steering geometry. However, in the case of a 6WD/6WS, the middle steering angle is a function of the front steering angle and it needs to be satisfied with an Ackerman steering geometry relation between the front and the middle steering angles. In the case of a small front steering angle, the radius of curvature of the steering motion is large. The front steering angle can be expressed by the radius of curvature and the wheel base of the 6WD/6WS vehicle as follows

The middle steering angle is expressed as a function of the wheel base from the centre of gravity to the middle wheels and the radius of curvature. Substituting equation (7) into the following equation
where

the middle steering angle is expressed as the front steering angle. Finally, substituting the radius of curvature, which is a function of velocity and yaw rate of the vehicle, into equation (8), the middle steering angle can be expressed by the wheel base and the front steering angle.
The steering angle input determined by the upper level controller is assigned to the front and middle steering angles.

sec.title: 3.2.2 Reference yaw rate calculation
sec.p: In many studies for a 4WD vehicle, the desired yaw rate model is calculated from the linear bicycle model. Also, the 6WD/6WS vehicle model can be regarded as a bicycle model for the control system design. Figure 9 shows the bicycle model for a 6WD/6WS vehicle.

caption.p: Bicycle model of a 6WD/6WS vehicle

sec.p: In the case of a low-speed driving condition where tyre slip is nearly zero, the centre of the vehicle steering motion is determined predominantly as point ‘A’. On the other hand, due to tyre slip generated in a high-speed driving condition, the centre of the vehicle steering motion is shifted from point ‘A’ to point ‘B’. It is necessary that the desired model contains the slip effect, which is generated in a high-speed condition. The state–space equation of the 6WD/6WS bicycle model is shown below. Because the middle steering angle depends on the front steering angle, inputs of a state–space equation can be written only by the front steering angle
where

The gain (k) of the steady state yaw rate (γss) can be obtained by excluding transient terms from the bicycle model in equation (9) and by substituting the side slip angle for the yaw rate. It is given as
A desired yaw rate is determined by the steady state yaw rate gain and first-order transfer function, expressed as a time constant
Assuming constant lateral velocity, the following equation provides a theoretical limit to the yaw rate that is achievable at the current friction condition between the tyre and road.
Therefore, the desired yaw rate is reasonably constrained by the physical limit of tyre–road friction as follows
In this study, the estimation of friction circles μiFzi has been conducted and will be described in section 4.

sec.title: 3.2.3 Yaw rate controller design using the sliding- mode control method
sec.p: To track the proposed desired yaw rate, a yaw rate controller is designed based on the 2 DOF bicycle model. The yaw rate controller generates a desired yaw moment to stabilize the dynamic behaviour of a vehicle. The 2 DOF bicycle model is given in Fig. 9. The yaw equation of the yaw motion of the 2 DOF bicycle model is considered when designing the yaw rate controller

In the bicycle model, lateral forces are regarded as a linear function of the slip angle, assuming that the slip angle is smaller than 3 degrees. Therefore, lateral forces are treated as non-linear functions and the bicycle model turns out to be a non-linear one.
In order to track the reference yaw rate, a yaw rate controller is designed using sliding-mode control theory. The bicycle model is considered as a first-order single-input system as follows
The sliding surface is defined as a yaw rate error, which is the difference between the actual yaw rate and the desired one, as follows
The control objective is to keep the scalar s at zero, which can be achieved by choosing the control law satisfying the following sliding condition
The sliding control law is obtained as the desired yaw moment as follows

sec.title: 3.2.4 Vehicle speed controller design
sec.p: A speed controller is designed to calculate the desired longitudinal net force in order to force the vehicle to follow the desired velocity using PID control as follows

sec.title: 3.3 Lower level controller design
sec.p: The proposed controller designed by an optimal control theory [15, 16] is suitable for an independent driving and steering vehicle equipped with six in-wheel motors and six steering motors. Figure 10 shows a block diagram of the lower level controller. In order to force the vehicle to follow the desired longitudinal net force and yaw moment calculated by the upper level controller, the lower level controller has been designed. This controller distributes the front lateral tyre force and the longitudinal tyre forces on each wheel.

caption.p: Block diagram of the lower level controller

sec.p: The distributed tyre forces are determined in proportion to the friction circle according to the change in driving conditions. Weighting factors are adjusted by the wheel load condition. The lower level controller consists of tyre force normalization, weighting factor calculation, and tyre force distribution.

sec.title: 3.3.1 Optimal distribution performance index and constraints
sec.p: Combinations of control inputs of a 6WD/6WS vehicle are relatively large, compared to those of a 4WD vehicle. Although improved performance can be achieved through high degree-of-freedom combinations, it is difficult to determine values of each input. In this paper, the control strategy determines the additional front lateral tyre force and differential traction/braking forces of six wheels according to the friction circle, as shown in Fig. 11. Candidates for a performance index can be significant combinations of control input. The proposed performance index is selected using the following method [17]. The minimum additional input is determined in such a way that the currently applied tyre force is considered and is proportional to the size of a friction circle. For a small-sized friction circle, the additional tyre force is limited to prevent an excessive slip ratio. As the maximum tyre force of a wheel that can be generated is improved, it is evident that there is an improvement in the performance compared to a conventional DYC.

caption.p: Optimal distribution strategy

sec.p: The performance index is made up of parameters of six wheels: longitudinal/lateral tyre forces, friction coefficient, and vertical tyre forces. The weighting factors in the performance index are changed according to the driving conditions. The performance index is given by

The weighting factors (Wxi, Wyi) can be adjusted to improve the control performance of the 6WD/6WS vehicle. Adjustment of the weighting factors will be described in the next section. Constraints are written as follows, where the desired longitudinal tyre force (Fx_des) and yaw moment (Mz) have been already determined by the upper level controller

The following equation represents the relationship between the left and right additional front lateral tyre forces, where the proportion between these additional front tyre forces is identical to the size of the friction circle

The number of independent variables was changed from eight to five through three constraints, such as equations (21), (22), and (23). In equation (23), an additional lateral tyre force applied on the front right wheel is a dependent variable, which is expressed as the front left additional lateral tyre force. The rear left and right longitudinal tyre forces are dependent variables that can be expressed as other independent variables as follows
Five independent variables that have previously been defined are solved by using the optimization method. Necessary conditions minimized for optimization are given as follows
where
The equations (26), (27), (29), (29), and (30) can be rewritten as follows

Matrices A and B are expressed by the friction coefficient, vertical tyre force, tread, wheel base, desired longitudinal tyre net forces, and desired net yaw moment. This linear equation is solved at each time step to find the optimal tyre force distribution. The steering angle can be determined using the linear lateral tyre model, considering the tyre force saturation as follows :

This control strategy is designed while assuming that the vertical tyre forces and tyre–road friction coefficients (μ) are known. Although this information cannot be directly measured, it can be estimated using other states of information for a 6WD/6WS vehicle. Estimator design for the friction circle estimation will be described in section 4.
Inputs of wheel torque are determined by the distributed longitudinal tyre forces and the radius of each tyre as follows

Since the distributed longitudinal tyre forces have been computed by considering physical limitations according to the friction circle of each wheel as described in equations (13) and (19), the distributed longitudinal net forces do not exceed the friction circle. Therefore, the slip ratio of the tyres can be limited.

sec.title: 3.3.2 Adjustment of weighting factors
sec.p: Tyre forces are distributed in proportional to the friction circle according to the change in driving conditions. However, the tyre force is limited in the case of severe braking and steering conditions. Figure 12 shows severe braking and an understeer situation. The direction of the driver’s steering demand is equal to that of the desired yaw moment. Additional longitudinal and lateral tyre forces are allocated to generate the desired yaw moment in a counterclockwise direction. However, the allocated longitudinal tyre forces cannot be generated due to the friction circle limitation in this case. It is necessary to allocate additional lateral tyre forces predominantly using a weighting factor adjustment.

caption.p: Limitation of generating additional longitudinal tyre forces

sec.p: Moreover, weighting factors can limit the desired tyre forces that exceed the friction circle. For this purpose, tyre force normalization needs to be conducted on an adjustment of the weighting factors. Tyre force normalization implies how much wheel can generate additional tyre forces. If a value of tyre force normalization approaches 1, no more additional tyre forces can be generated. Increasing the weighting factors can restrict additional tyre forces from exceeding the range of the friction circle. A value of tyre force normalization is calculated as follows
Theta (θ) is determined as follows
where θ implies an angle of longitudinal and lateral tyre force, as shown in Fig. 13.

caption.p: Concept of a normalized tyre force and theta

sec.p: Weighting factors are a function of the normalized tyre force. The weighting factor is calculated by the normalized tyre force, as follows

If the weighting factor is smaller than 1, the weighting factor has to be fixed to 1. When the normalized tyre force approaches 1, the weighting factors rapidly increase to a large value that is greater than 1. The parameters kWx and yshift represent control parameters. Figure 14 shows that the weighting factor is adjusted to coordinate optimal additional tyre forces properly according to the normalized tyre force. The wheel load condition can be changed according to the driving situation. Additional longitudinal tyre forces should be determined by considering the friction circle and longitudinal weighting factor (Wx) adjustment. On the other hand, the proposed system is equipped with independent steering actuators. The lower level controller should determine the longitudinal and lateral weighting factor (Wy) due to limitation of the longitudinal or lateral tyre forces. Longitudinal and lateral weighting factors are calculated according to the proportion of longitudinal and lateral tyre forces that are applied on the front wheels.

caption.p: Weighting factor according to the normalized tyre force

sec.p: The lateral weighting factor is determined as follows
where kWy is an exponential parameter that can change the proportion of Wy to Wx with respect to θ.

sec.title: 3.4 Direct yaw moment controller design for a mechanical drive system
sec.p: A mechanical system equipped with a DYC has been developed to compare the proposed optimal coordination controller with respect to performance of manoeuvrability and stability. The direct yaw moment controller (DYC) introduced in this paper is modified appropriately for a 6WD/6WS vehicle. Figure 15 shows a block diagram of the DYC.

caption.p: DYC block diagram

sec.p: The desired yaw moment is calculated by the upper level controller based on the sliding-mode control theory. The upper level controller of the DYC is identical to that of the optimal coordination controller. Longitudinal tyre forces are determined using

sec.title: 3.4.1 Effective control wheel decision
sec.p: Longitudinal and lateral tyre forces in the individual wheels are coupled with each other. The lateral tyre force tends to decrease with an increase in the longitudinal one. Also, different geometric features of each wheel have a different effect on generating the yaw moment. In conclusion, a dominant effect wheel is determined through the direction of the desired yaw moment and turning of a 6WD/6WS vehicle.

Figure 16 shows the change of yaw moment in the case where the vehicle is turning left at 100 km/h. The input torque is applied independently to each wheel. The reason why positive moment is generated without input torque on each wheel is that the steering angle has been applied in order to turn left. To generate yaw moment in the opposite direction, it is most effective to apply input torque on the outer front wheel of the turning direction. Similarly, to generate yaw moment in the same direction as turning motion, it is most effective to assign input torque on the inner rear wheel of the turning direction.

caption.p: Yaw moment generation by the individual braking force at each wheel

sec.p: Table 2 shows the effective braking wheel according to the direction of the desired yaw moment. In case I, the directions of the steering manoeuvre and required yaw moment are identical and counterclockwise. In this case, the effective braking wheel is the rear left wheel. In case II, the direction of the steering manoeuvre is counterclockwise and the direction of the required yaw moment is clockwise. In this case, the effective wheel is the front right wheel. In case III, the directions of the steering manoeuvre and required yaw moment are identical and clockwise. In this case, the effective braking wheel is the rear right wheel. In case IV, the direction of the steering manoeuvre is clockwise and the direction of the required yaw moment is counterclockwise. In this case, the effective braking wheel is the front left wheel.

caption.p: Effective braking wheel

sec.title: 3.4.2 Brake torque distribution
sec.p: In the previous section, the effective braking wheel is chosen by the yaw moment controller according to several driving conditions. The braking pressure is applied to the braking wheel, which can generate yaw moment. In braking pressure distribution, the effective braking wheel has the largest braking pressure, the braking pressure of the middle wheel is smaller than that of the effective braking wheel, and braking pressure of the other wheel is the smallest. The lower level controller is designed to use an efficient maximum braking force in order to satisfy the desired yaw moment. The performance of the DYC achieves more improvement of lateral stability than a conventional DYC, like an ESC equipped for general vehicles. Figure 17 shows the distribution strategy for several driving conditions.

caption.p: Yaw moment generation by the individual braking force at each wheel

sec.p: The distributed force of an effective wheel is 50 per cent of the total braking force and the same side middle wheel is 30 per cent. The braking force of the other wheel is 15 per cent. The distributed force in each case is given by

sec.title: 4 Friction Circle and Tyre Force Estimator for the Optimal Coordination Controller
4.1 Design of the friction circle estimator
sec.p: For the implementation of the optimal coordination controller, it is necessary to measure vertical tyre forces and the friction coefficient. The information of the vertical tyre forces and the friction coefficient are important in the computation of the optimized additional tyre forces. However, these are difficult or very expensive to be measured directly. The friction circle is defined as the maximum tyre force that can be generated on each wheel. In other words, the friction circle represents multiplication of the vertical tyre force and the friction coefficient. Estimating the friction circle is more convenient than estimating the vertical tyre force and the friction coefficient separately on off-road driving conditions.

The estimator consists of a longitudinal tyre force estimation, slip ratio estimation, and friction circle estimation, as shown in Fig. 18. The available sensor signals are the longitudinal vehicle velocity, wheel speed, wheel angular acceleration, and wheel torque. The longitudinal vehicle velocity can be obtained from the GPS/INS integration system implemented with the 6WD/6WS vehicle.

caption.p: The structure of the friction circle estimator

sec.p: Vehicle sensors are interfaced with the controllers using a control area network (CAN). Because of the measured discrete digital signal from the sensors, the friction circle estimator should take the resolution and noise of sensors into account
The longitudinal tyre force can be simply estimated using the wheel input torque and wheel angular acceleration based on the wheel dynamics, as shown by

The wheel angular acceleration can be estimated by measuring the wheel angular velocity and the wheel dynamic equation. The discrete-time state equation of the estimation of the wheel angular acceleration is obtained from the Taylor formula of wheel angular velocity as [18]
In equation (42), ΔT measures the update period and di(k) represents higher-order terms. The wheel angular velocity can be measured as
As a result, the state equation is expressed by discretizing equations (42) and (43) as
In equations (44), v(k) is measurement noise. Suppose di(k) and v(k) are zero-mean white noise separately, whose covariance values are Q(k) and R(k) as follows
The angular acceleration can be estimated using a Kalman filter, where L(k) denotes the Kalman filter gain. Finally, the wheel angular acceleration can be obtained with
The slip ratio is estimated using the longitudinal vehicle velocity and wheel angular velocity. The slip ratio is defined as

The friction circle can be estimated using the estimated longitudinal tyre force and slip ratio. Firstly, the longitudinal tractive/braking stiffness is defined in order to grasp road friction conditions and the applied vertical tyre force. The longitudinal tractive/braking stiffness changes according to the size of the friction circle. In the case of a large friction circle, which represents the high friction condition and the applied vertical tyre force, the longitudinal tractive/braking stiffness has a larger value. On the other hand, the small friction circle decreases the longitudinal tractive/braking stiffness. This means that the friction circle is proportional to the longitudinal tractive/braking stiffness, which is a gradient of the slip ratio–longitudinal tyre force relation (the magic formula). The longitudinal tractive/braking stiffness is calculated as follows
The relationship between the estimated friction circle and the nominal friction circle is as follows

The nominal friction circle is defined by the friction coefficient and the static vertical tyre force, which can be measured by the tyre test. The size of the friction circle can be determined using a proportional relationship between the size of the friction circle and the longitudinal tractive/braking stiffness. In order to calculate the size of the estimated friction circle, the nominal friction circle and the nominal longitudinal tractive/braking stiffness are used as a basis. The friction circle can be estimated as follows
Constant K is determined by the nominal friction circle and the longitudinal tractive/braking stiffness. The nominal and estimated slip ratio should be in the linear region.

However, if the nominal longitudinal tractive/braking stiffness changes, the friction circle is not estimated accurately. The slope of the longitudinal tyre force in the linear range depends on the slip angle, as illustrated in Fig. 19. When the vehicle speed is 100 km/h and the steering wheel angle is less than 1.5 deg, the slip angle is less than 4 deg, and lateral acceleration is less than 3 m/s2. Figure 20 shows the comparison of the slip angle and the lateral acceleration when the vehicle is in the stable and unstable regions at 100 km/h. The steering wheel input is sinusoidal and the frequency is 0.5 Hz. If the magnitude of the steering wheel angle is greater than 1.5 deg and the vehicle velocity is 100 km/h, the vehicle becomes unstable. However, at less than 1.5 deg, the slip angle is maintained in a range of −4 to 4 deg and the lateral acceleration is in the range of −3 to 3 m/s2.

caption.p: Relationship between the longitudinal tractive/braking stiffness and the friction circle
(a) Slip angle, and (b) and lateral acceleration according to the steering angle input in the stable region

sec.p: The slip angle has an effect on the longitudinal tyre force slope according to the combined tyre dynamics [14], as shown in Fig. 21. However, when the slip angle is less than 4 deg in the stable region, the effect of the slip angle on the longitudinal tyre force slope is slightly affected in the stable region. In this paper, the stability of the vehicle can be guaranteed by the proposed controller in the high-speed and severe driving situations. The friction circle estimation can be estimated by the proposed algorithm.

caption.p: Changes in the slopes of the longitudinal tyre force–slip ratio lines due to the slip angle

sec.title: 4.2 Design of the lateral tyre force estimator
sec.p: In order to adjust the weighting factors on the lower level controller, it is necessary to estimate the lateral tyre forces. The slip angle is estimated as follows
where
The lateral tyre forces are estimated by Pacejka tyre model (magic formula) using the estimated slip angle and friction circle

sec.title: 4.3 Simulation results
sec.p: The performance of the friction circle estimator has been evaluated via computer simulations. A lane change manoeuvre was conducted and initial velocity sets to 90 km/h. Figures 22(a) to (f) show friction circle estimation results. Figures 22(c) and (d) show the longitudinal and lateral tyre force estimation results. Figure 22(f) is the friction circle estimation results. The friction circle estimation result reflects severe friction coefficient change. The vehicle experiences a step change of tyre road friction coefficient from 0.9 to 0.5 at 3 seconds.

caption.p: Estimation results

sec.title: 5 Simulation Results
sec.p: The response of a 6WD/6WS vehicle with the driving controller is evaluated via computer simulations using the Matlab/Simulink dynamic model. A closed-loop simulation of a double-lane change manoeuvre using a driver model [19] is conducted to investigate the improved performance of the proposed optimal coordination controller in comparison to the DYC. In this simulation, the steering wheel angle is determined by a driver model for tracking the reference path. A double-lane change manoeuvre is simulated on a low friction coefficient road condition (μ = 0.5). The initial vehicle speed is 70 km/h and the deceleration is −2 m/s2. Figures 23 and 24 show the simulation results of a 6WD/6WS vehicle. In the case of no control, longitudinal tyre forces are coordinated identically to generate the desired vehicle velocity. The optimal coordination controller enhances the performance over the DYC and no control with respect to the yaw rate error and side slip angle, as shown in Figs 24(a) and (b). In Fig. 24(c), the lateral error is smaller than the DYC and no control cases. The yaw rate error is larger than the optimal coordination case because of the excessive wheel slip of the tyre in a low friction driving condition. In the case of no control, the vehicle velocity decreases significantly because of spin-out. In the case of the DYC, applied brake pressure for the DYC exceeds the desired longitudinal net force. Thus, the deceleration of the vehicle is greater than the desired deceleration for the vehicle velocity control. In the case of the optimal coordination control, the vehicle velocity is almost identical to the reference vehicle velocity, as shown in Fig. 24(d). The calculated brake torques from the DYC is larger than the size of the friction circle in this manoeuvre, because the DYC does not take the size of the friction circle into account. On the other hand, the optimal distribution controller, which considers the size of a friction circle, coordinates proper additional longitudinal and lateral tyre forces, as shown in Figs 24(e) and (f), giving the DYC case and the optimal coordination controller, respectively. In the optimal coordination control case, the desired tyre force is calculated inside of the friction circle range.

caption.p: Trajectories of no control, DYC, and optimal coordination control closed-loop simulation cases (μ = 0.5)
Closed-loop simulation results of no control, DYC, and optimal coordination control cases (μ = 0.5)

sec.title: 6 Conclusion
sec.p: An optimal coordination controller for a 6WD/6WS vehicle has been proposed to improve stability and manoeuvrability. The optimal coordination controller was designed taking into consideration the friction circle. The weighting factors in the optimal performance index are adjusted according to the change in the centre of gravity. The size of the friction circle was estimated using vehicle state information, which can be measured by sensors. The response of the 6WD/6WS vehicle with the optimal coordination controller has been evaluated via computer simulations. Closed-loop simulation of a double-lane change manoeuvre using a driver model has been conducted to investigate the improved performance of the proposed optimal coordination controller in comparison with the DYC. Simulation results showed that the performance and stability of the 6WD/6WS vehicle can be significantly improved by the proposed optimal coordination controller, compared to the DYC with respect to the yaw rate, the side slip angle, and the lateral position error.
Real-time simulation using the hardware-in-the-loop simulator (HILS) and field tests using the test vehicle are the topics of future research by the authors.
